item.title: Report E-2024070517
item.description:
Report E-2024070517

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-24T15:14:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-19
  • City: GREENWOOD
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately two (2) pints of material released from one (1) 275-gallon poly tote due to a loose cap. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and containerized the cleanup debris into one (1) 10-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070518
item.description:
Report E-2024070518

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-19
  • City: GREENWOOD
  • State: IN

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately two and a half (2.5) gallons of material released form one (1) 5-gallon metal pail due to load shift that crushed the container. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed absorbents to the impacted area and containerized the recovered material into one (1) 8-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) cup of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to a small puncture in the body of the drum. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerize the recovered spent absorbents and the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight ’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) liter of material released from one (1) 5-gallon plastic jerrycan due to a load shift during transit. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area, and the cleanup debris was containerized into one (1) 15-gallon poly drum along with the damaged jerrycan. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2024071519
item.description:
Report X-2024071519

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-24T15:14:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: BESSEMER
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Federal Express Corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package consists of a fiberboard box containing 4 plastic bottles, each in a plastic bag. One of the caps was either very loose or defective, as it came off completely during inspection. Contents were not contained by the plastic bag, and leaked out, ruining the box. The spill reached a section of rollers and 1 other known package (777213356566). Spill area was covered in neutralizing absorbent powder, then swept and then contained in a lined salvage bin.

I tested the pH and found it to be around 12. Upon inspection I found the cap was loose on one of the inner jugs causing it to leak. I secured the package in a lined HazMat tote and placed it in the HWSA.

  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately fifteen (15) gallons of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to falling freight that punctured the drum resulting in the released material impacting the trailer floor. item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-17
  • City: MARSHFIELD
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XSJ experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK 50 release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor and tote body due to a broken gasket. The crew retrieved a new gasket and repaired the tote for shipment on. The impacted areas were cleaned and wiped down with absorbent pads. All waste was placed into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-16
  • City: ALBANY
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: FORTY-SEVEN AIR PACKAGES EACH MARKED AND LABELED WITH CLASS 9 DIAMOND LABELS, UN1845, AND DRY ICE 2.5 KGS. THE PACKAGES CONTAINED FOOD PRODUCTS FROZEN WITH UN1977, NITROGEN, REFRIGERATED LIQUID, DIVISION 2.2 INSTEAD OF UN1845 DRY ICE, CLASS 9. THE PACKAGES WERE OFFERED AIR SERVICE BUT WERE DISCOVERED AT THE ORIGIN PICKUP FACILITY PRIOR TO AIRCRAFT CONTAINER SCANS. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO. THE NITROGEN, REFRIGERATED LIQUID INSIDE EACH PACKAGE WAS NOT OFFERED IN A MANNER ASCERTAINABLE AT THE TIME OF ACCEPTANCE, THUS REPORTABLE UNDER 49CFR 175.31(B). THE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM OREGON USING UPS ACCOUNT JA1916, OREGON VALLEY FARM, 2280 THREE LAKES RD SE, ALBANY OREGON 97322.

SUPERVISORS THEN NOTIFIED HAZMAT RESPONDER/AUDITOR WHO DONNED PPE AND INSPECTED PACKAGE IN SPILL TOTE AND IDENTIFIED THE CONTENTS. ONCE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT CONTENTS WERE HAZARDOUS AND NO IDENTIFYING MARKINGS WERE ON CARTON, CONTACTED THE HMSC UNDER THE CAPACITY OF A HAZMAT AUDITOR AND REPORTED IT AS AN UNDECLARED HAZMAT SHIPMENT.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AN UNLOADER WAS UNLOADING ONE OF THE PACKAGE CARS AT OUR FACILITY AND HEARD RATTLING SOUND OF AEROSOL CANS WHILE HANLDING ONE OF THE PACKAGES. AN ACCEPTANCE AUDITOR WAS NOTIFIED AND THE PACKAGE WAS INSPSECTED. THE PACKAGE WAS FOUND TO CONTAIN AEROSOL CANS AND WAS PROCESSED AS AN UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS SHIPMENT.

item.title: Report X-2024071491
item.description:
Report X-2024071491

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDED TO CALL AT DOOR 37. DONNED FULL P.P.E. GOGGLES, APRON, GLOVES, SILVER SHIELD LINERS, BOOTS. UPON ENTERING THE TRAILER DISCOVERED LEAKING LIMITED QUANTITY PACKAGE ON FLOOR. FOR SAFETY MOVED UNDAMAGES AND UNSOILED PACKAGES OUT OF WAY. DISCOVERED A SEPARATE LEAKER IN THAT TIER. RESPONDED TO EACH CALL SEPARATELY PER DECISION-TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEETS. CLEANED UP BOTH LEAKERS AND CONTAINERIZED EACH LEAKER SEPARATELY. BROUGHT BACK TO PSC FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. UPON OPENING ONE OF THE AFFECTED PACKAGES IN TIER DISCOVERED AEROSOL CANS WITH NO EXTERNAL MARKINGS INDICATING A LIMITED QUANTITY. ADVISED RMP WHO REVIEWED AND TOOK PHOTOS OF ALL SIDES, LABEL AND INSIDE. PROCESSING AS AN UNDECLARED PER DISCUSSION WITH RMP. RMP CONTACT HMSC TO REPORT UNDECLARED

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-28
  • City: ABILENE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal LAB. ERTS dispatched DSC Environmental to assist with cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of product released to a 7’ x 20’ area of the trailer floor and an 8’ x 6’ area of the concrete lot below due to a puncture. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The damaged drum, impacted absorbents, and cleanup debris were containerized into (2) 95-gallon poly drums. The waste was stored onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.title: Report E-2024070110
item.description:
Report E-2024070110

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: MARION
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 33ft-by-1ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to crushed freight due to hard braking damaging twelve (12) plastic bottles. First Call personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and then used a granular absorbent to gather the neutralized material. The spent absorbents were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and the damaged bottles were placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was transported to the nearest ESTES terminal. The damaged bottles were then combined with the spent absorbents. The 55-gallon poly drum was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor’s demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024070014
item.description:
Report I-2024070014

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 06:09 AM on 06/24/24 I recieved notification that the tank car had sloshed product (Substituted Phenol) from under the manway. The car was located in track 47 at our North Yard, the shipper was contacted and they elected to use our Haz-Mat Contractor M&M Protection LLC to respond. Upon arrival it was noted that all 8 swing bolts were less than tool tight and the gasket was worn. These issues were corrected by M&M, new gasket, swing bolts tighten in a star pattern with no more evidence of product leaking. The car was washed and all spillage/residue was remediated.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-29
  • City: SAN FRANCISCO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Halfway through the flight, passenger 20A, told FA Pang that their laptop was emitting an electrical smell. FA conferred with FM and both agreed there was a smell. No flames, heat, or smoke were present. Out of an abundance of caution, the MacBook Pro was placed into the TCB. The TCB was placed in an aft lav and monitored occasionally per CA instructions occasionally throughout the flight. The TCB remained in the aft lav until descent, in which it was brought to the forward lav for easy access upon door opening. Due to no signs of fire, smoke, or heat, pax was escorted to the exit and was able to retrieve the laptop out of the TCB. FAs reminded to fill out IORs and thanked for erring on the side of caution.

item.title: Report I-2024060052
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-20T00:36:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-25
  • City: MILLINGTON
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 166135
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: An East Penn Logistics, LLC driver was on Cypress Road Maryland, Rt 291, heading towards the Maryland / Delaware line. While checking in his mirrors he drifted right, went off the road into a ditch and tried to recover back onto the road and over corrected and ended in a roll over onto the driver's side. The driver was treated for minor injuries. The local Police responded to the scene. They called a local towing company to assist in the clean up and the towing of the truck. The Maryland Department of Environment also responded to the call. By the time they arrived, the incident was mostly cleaned up. They were happy with the clean up and no further action to be done via the MD EPA for clean up. The truck and batteries were towed back to Phillips Garage in Sudlersville, MD. The driver returned the next day to help repalletize and package the scrap batteries for shipping back to East Penn Manufacturing, Lyons Station for proper disposal of the batteries at our secondary lead smelter.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: The freight was not secured in the trailer coming from Pitt Ohio with a trailer seal on the door. As the trailer was moving to Ross/Auburn, MA terminal the freight shifted and 1 box of 6 boxes shift, broke open causing 4 cans to be damaged as cans of paint leaked in the trailer. The paint only leaked in the yard when the doors were opened. No paint reached any drains. Paint cleanup was performed after it was determined what the proper HM clean up procedure needed to be followed to protect Ross employees. A dock employee then took the damaged box of paint off the pallet in the trailer. The damaged- 1 box/4- 1 gallon cans and cleaning materials used for cleanup were placed in a recovery drum for disposal.

The release was due to the pail falling off of the pallet as a result of improper loading. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents and damaged pail were then collected into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

EWI personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon poly overpack. Crews deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and asphalt and swept them up with hand tools. Two (2) 55-gallon drums of neutralized product and any cleanup debris, and the one (1) 95-gallon overpack of the damaged drum were staged onsite for disposal.

  • Description: On July 11, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3266 was punctured by a nail and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel deployed soda ash to the UN3266-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All soda ash and the damaged drum were placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: RESPONDER RESPONDEDED TO LEAKER AT DOOR 18 WITH ALL PPE FOLLOWED THE DECISION TREE FOLLOWED THE PROCEDURE THE PACKAGE WAS SITTING UPRIGHT IN THE TRAILER WITH SMALL WET SPOT IN BOTTOM CORNER OF THE BOX THERE WAS NO OTHER VISIBLE DAMAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN CLEANED UP, NO PUDDLE EXISTED ON FLOOR. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN TRANSPORTED BACK TO DMP WHERE IT WAS REFRENCED IN ETT AND OPERATORS QUICK REFERENCE GUIDE. THE PACKAGE WAS NEUTRALIZED WITH SODIUM BICARBONATE AND THEN ABSORBED WITH ZEP ZORBANT.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-29
  • City: BROCKWAY
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLI TRANSPORT, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our tanker vehicle loaded full with 87 Gasoline was struck by another vehicle. Our trailer required to be towed. Before it was towed the damaged trailer was emptied by a third party company with a pumping truck, into an empty secondary tanker we had brought onto location. In the events of the pumping truck transferring the product, the pumping company did not verify that all of the product was transferred from one tank of the damaged truck to the corresponding tank of the new truck. In doing so, our 1100 gallon tank was overfilled and 20 gallons of gasoline was pushed out of the vapor recovery line on our trailer. The third party company used absorbent mats, brooms, absorbent socks, and clean up powder to mitigate the effects of the release.

Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-4ft area of the trailer floor and a 1ft-by-3ft area of concrete underneath the trailer and estimated that eight (8) cups of material was released due to the valve being semi open. New England Disposal Technologies personnel neutralized the impacted areas and deployed absorbents. The remaining material in the leaking tote was transferred to a new tote. The leaking tote and recovered material were cut up and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums for disposal.

Clean Harbors personnel deployed absorbents and then swept up the released material. The damaged drums were overpacked into three (3) 95-gallon poly drums. The recovered material and spent absorbents were placed into three (3) 55-gallon metal drums and two (2) 30-gallon poly drums and were staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

  • Description: XPO- XDE contacted ERTS regarding a leaking 250-gallon metal tote containing hazardous product, Zinc Octoate 8%. A Contractor discovered that the lid to the tote was loose and likely the cause of the release. It was estimated that 5-gallons of product spilled from the lid impacting the metal tote itself, the wooden trailer floor, and the steel grate on trailer floor. The total impact are was estimated to be 6’x6’. The Contractor was able to tighten the lid and perform a slosh test confirming that adjustments made to the lid were successful and the tote is in proper working order to ship on to the Consignee. One 55-gallon DM was generated for waste disposal containing impacted cardboard, PPE, and absorbent pads/rags. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While unloading, one 2,450Ib tote was discovered leaking. Area was isolated and contractor was dispatched. GrayMar Environmental responded to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, GrayMar Environmental inspected the leaking tote and determined the cap was faulty, which resulted in the release of approximately 0.5 gallon of product. Free product released to trailer floor and dock at customer location. GrayMar Environmental used absorbent material and rags to wipe the area clean, and transferred the leaking tote into a recovery tote to be sent on to the consignee. One 55-gallon drum of spent absorbent and cleanup debris was generated during the cleanup. Product was contained to an impervious surface and did not impact soil or threaten to impact state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While reversing into dock area at PepsiCo facility, vehicle struck another truck in lot, which damaged the saddle tank. Approximately 20 gallons of Diesel fuel were released to the asphalt surface and a minimal amount migrated to the nearby storm drain. PepsiCo personnel contained the release, and ACT Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, ACT Environmental applied absorbent material to the affected asphalt and inspected the nearby storm drain. Absorbent pads were utilized within storm drain catch basin to soak free product, and no further residual remained. Product was contained to the storm drain catch basin and did not migrate through drainage system. All spent absorbent material and pads were recovered and containerized into one 55-gallon drum, pending disposal in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. During delivery, the vent line failed, which resulted in the release of approximately 50 gallons of gasoline to the asphalt parking lot and nearby storm drain. The Local Fire Department responded to assess and applied absorbent material to contain the release. First Call Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, First Call Environmental applied additional absorbent material, which was worked in and recovered. First Call Environmental utilized a drum vacuum to recover the free product from the storm drain catch basin, and confirmed product was contained to catch basin and did not migrate through the sewer system. Two 55-gallon drums of spent absorbent material were generated during the cleanup. There was no impact to soils or threat to state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Description: On Thursday, 05/02/2024, at approximately 5:25am ET. Standard Petroleum's driver was ' traveling on the 1-95 - southbound in the right lane (of3). As Standard Petroleum's driver approached exit 14 on 1-95 southbound, a black Chevy Camaro struck Standard Petroleum's upper right side as the Camaro driver crossed a solid white line when it merged into traffic. After striking Standard Petroleum's vehicle, the Camaro then struck a trailer traveling parallel to Standard Petroleum m the middle lane, which caused the trailer to strike Standard Petroleum's vehicle. The cause of the failure is still being investigated; however, it is Standard Petroleum s understanding that the trailer struck Standard Petroleum's fuel tank which caused a fuel leak. Since the investigation is ongoing, Standard Petroleum is not able to describe the package failure with specificity at this time. ?nee Standard Petroleum's driver discovered the fuel leak, he immediately called 911 and notified Stand ard Petroleum dispatch of the incident. It is Standard Petroleum's unders!anding that either DEEP or Connecticut State Police notified Standard Republic, who is an environmental first responder for the State of Connecticut, to remedy the fuel leak.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal BCO experienced a UN2924 Silquest A-1101 Silane release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 ounces of product released to the metal tote body only. The plug on the top of the tote was missing which caused the release. The hole was plugged and a slosh test was completed which determined there would be no further release. The tote was wiped down, confirmed neutral, and confirmed secured for shipment on. The impacted pads and PPE were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

While the lab was analyzing the sample the dome of the trailer was laid down but not shut completely. The temperature outside was ~90F. The material in the tanker started to get hot and run out of the dome and onto the ground. 1 gallon of material leaked into secondary containment and was cleaned up in house. The cause of the spill was that the tanker was overfilled.

item.title: Report E-2024070381
item.description:
Report E-2024070381

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: JEFFERSONVILLE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 75000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 8, 2024, at 1745 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Jefferson, Georgia regarding the release of Caustic Soda Prills. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of Caustic Soda Prills (UN1823, 8, II). The release was caused by a rollover accident that impacted a 360ft x 50ft area of soil and an adjacent concrete lined drainage ditch that contained 635 gallons of free-standing impacted rainwater. Contractors collected the damaged cargo that was still in the trailer, neutralized and collected all free-standing liquid with a vac truck, excavated all impacted soil, then placed seed and straw. Contractors took 635 gallons of impacted rainwater in a vac truck and 11 roll-offs of impacted soil and damaged cargo offsite for proper disposal.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AIR PACKAGE FROM GERMANY TO THE USA WAS BEING INSPECTED BY USA CBP OFFICIALS WHO DISCOVERED UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED EIGHT BOOKS OF SAFETY MATCHES, FOUR AMICHAUF HEATING KITS CONTAINING SIX COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLETS AND ELEVEN ADDITIONAL COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLETS. THE COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLES ARE REGULATED AS UN1328, HEXAMETHYLENETETRAMINE, 4.1, PG III. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX.

  • City: BRATTLEBORO

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Crew 606 in Brattleboro VT reported a railcar loaded with hydrochloric acid on the adjacent track leaking from the dome. Emergency responders were called to the scene, contained the leak, and released pressure from the tank to stop the leak. Less than 5 gallons leaked out. It was discovered that there was a missing gasket and a defective (worn) gasket. Hepaco did cleanup and repairs, Car Owner (Reagent Chemical) did leak test, and TRC Environmental Consulting did reporting

item.title: Report I-2024070004
item.description:
Report I-2024070004

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-22
  • City: GRAFTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2100
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Checking the transfer line, the associate noticed Van 53022 (FCI) was leaking onto the gravel. The associate notified the foreman and pulled the van onto the concrete roadway to get it off the gravel. We assessed the area and then we took the van to the CSF to be offloaded to find the leaking container. About halfway in the trailer we found the drum with a dime size hole in it and the contents had all leaked onto the trailer floor except for approx. 15 gal. We finished unloading the van and we processed the load. We cleaned the trailer floor with floor dry. We also cleaned the TL and the drive. The material that leaked onto the drive stained the concrete. The Transfer Line spill on the gravel was approx. 1 gal. it was contained in a 3 foot radius pot hole so we added floor dry to absorb the material. We took a before and after sample to the lab with the cin. (519142) we used on the drum that leaked. All effected areas have been cleaned. We generated 1 (1/4 Full) Tote. Tote is labeled with a Haz. Label with the info. needed and placed in the on hold area.

item.title: Report E-2024070369
item.description:
Report E-2024070369

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-20
  • City: ATLANTA
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HERITAGE TRANSPORT, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10200
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The IBC was strapped in the trailer by Heritage Crystal Clean (HCC). Heritage Environmental Services (HES) employees unloaded the trailer at the Heritage Transport (HT) transfer facility. HES employees loosen the load strap which exposed a whole in the body of the IBC. The whole was 1 inch or less in size. The whole was located approximately halfway down the side of the body. HES employees secured and blocked nearby storm drains and contact an emergency response contractor to mitigate the release, transfer the remaining contents of the damaged IBC to a new container, to recover the spilled material, and to containerize absorbent materials. The duration of the release was approximately 90 minutes.

  • Description: At approximately 12:16 PM on 06/14/24 notification was received that the tank car was leaking product (Diesel Fuel) from the manway. The car was isolated in track 1 at North Yard and we immediately contacted our Haz-Mat Contractor M&M Protection LLC to respond. Upon arrival it was noted that the swing bolts were less than tool tight and there was no rim gasket. These issues were immediately corrected by M&M and the leak was stopped.

  • Description: It was reported that unknown amount of Washington Mills UN3077 Cryolite Synthetic Powder released from one (1) Gaylord bag. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and dispatched Hepaco to the site to assist with clean up. Hepaco responded and observed approximately 10-pounds of Cryolite released from the damaged plastic gaylord. The release impacted a 10’X23’ area on the trailer floor. No drains or soil were impacted. Hepaco recovered the Cryolite. Hepaco unloaded the trailer, used simple green rags, wiped down the trailer, freighted, and reloaded the trailer. Hepaco created one 5-gallon poly drum of waste. Hepaco left the waste on-site with the XPO dock manager.

  • Description: At approximately 04:36 AM on 06/09/24 notification was received that the tank car was leaking product (Argon Gas) from the valve on the vent pipe. The car was located on the south end of our Pasadena Yard and we immediately contacted our Haz-Mat Contractor M&M Protection LLC to respond. Upon arrival it was noted that the road isolation valve was in the open position and the gas line closed with the equalizer open as well as the liquid vaporizer sample line was left open. These issues were immediately corrected by M&M and the leak was stopped.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSL experienced a UN1992 19122 Lacquer Thinner Fast release from (6) 5-gallon metal pails. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 10’ area of the trailer floor. The lids of the pails seemed to be leaking as a possible result of being stacked and crushed. The damaged pails were collected into an 85-gallon poly drum. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents, pads, pallet pieces, and PPE were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On July 5th, during the PM sort a pallet of drums was found leaking. The drums contained UN1263, Paint, 3, III. Two of the drums were damaged at the handles, one was damaged at the top chime, the last one was damaged at the bottom chime. The four leaking drums were placed into a steel salvage drums and amended shippers declarations were requested.

item.title: Report E-2024070299
item.description:
Report E-2024070299

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-17T18:15:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-05
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 5, 2024, one (1) 20-pound box of UN2277 was damaged by a nail and released approximately twenty (20) pounds of product to the truck interior. The monomer product experienced a polymerization reaction and damaged additional containers. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Crews observed heat and vapor created from the polymerization process and contained and isolated the reacting product. All product was containerized into thirteen (13) 55-gallon vented poly drums. LSH utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted trailer and dock. All impacted debris and PPE were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.
